H0.text: Flowering plants are thought to have evolved at least 200 million years ago from gymnosperms like gnetae.

H1.text: Yeasts are thought to have evolved at least 200 million years ago from gymnosperms like gnetae.

H2.text: Cone-bearing plants are thought to have evolved at least 200 million years ago from gymnosperms like gnetophytes.

H3.text: Deciduous trees are thought to have evolved at least 200 million years ago from gymnosperms such as gnetophytes.

A4.text: Molecular evidence suggests that the ancestors of angiosperms diverged from the gymnosperms during the late Devonian, about 365 million years ago.

A5.text: The ancestors of flowering plants diverged from the common ancestor of all living gymnosperms before the end of the Carboniferous, over 300 million years ago.

A6.text: A 2018 phylogenomic study estimated the divergence between Gnetales and Pinaceae at around 241 million years ago, in the early Triassic, while a 2021 study placed it earlier, in the Carboniferous.
